title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text: In this hands on exercise, we will go through the ggplot packages of R and apply the the principle of Layered Grammar of Graphic.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
Install and Import R packages
The code chunk below use the p_load function of pacman packages to check if tidyverse packages is installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be imported to R.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
R Graphic vs ggplot

R Graphicggplot



hist(exam_data$MATHS)







ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")







from the comparison above can be seen that even though R Graphic codes are simpler, the ggplot has more room for flexibility.
Also, Pointed out by Hadley Wickham
“The transferable skills from ggplot2 are not the idiosyncrasies of plotting syntax, but a powerful way of thinking about visualisation, as a way of mapping between variables and the visual properties of geometric objects that you can perceive.”

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_bar
geom_bar utilised to plot bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_dotplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.





dotplot is used to plot dots. Each dot represent a single observation. However, the y-axis is showing something else which is wrong. Therefore, we can turned off or remove the y-axis using the scale_y_continuous.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_histogram()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()       

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.





geom histogram is to plot histogram with default bin of 30

text:
Geometric Objects: geom-density()
plot the kernel density plot, smoothed histogram

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_boxplot
creating box plot to show the median, two hinges and two whiskers, and all “outlying” points individually.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()            




Notches are used in box plots to help visually assess whether the medians of distributions differ. If the notches do not overlap, this is evidence that the medians are different.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
text:

violin is to visualised if two different plot or data has similar distribution

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()

multiple geoms can be drawn into the same graphic

ggplot(data=exam_data,

           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics: ggplot2 methods
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?
geom_smooth used to add fit line to the scatter plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size=0.5)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'





the default method of geom smooth is loess, below is how to set to other method of fit line

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Getting started

Importing the required libraries
there are 4 new libraries that are going to be utilised in this hands on. They are:

ggrepel: to repel overlapping text
ggthemes: to provide wider themes, geoms, and scales for ggplot2
hrbrthemes: to provide typography-centric themes and theme componens for ggplot2
patchwork: to combine figures


pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, ggthemes, hrbrthemes, tidyverse)



Importing the data
the data that will be used in this hands-on is exam data

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Beyond ggplot2 annotation: ggrepel
First, we look on the plot without using the ggrepel

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
                 y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm,
              size = 0.5) +
  geom_label(aes(label=ID),
             hjust = .5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores")




There are too much annotation that you cannot see anything anymore

working with ggrepel

The plotThe code










ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm,
              size = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID),
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Math schores for Primary 3")




now the annotation are not overlapping and only shown when possible

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Beyond ggplot2 themes
there are some built in themes from ggplot such as theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal() and some more.

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Math scores")





ggtheme
ggtheme is part of ggplot. However, it is open for extension therefore there are more ggplot that created by communities, theme_economist() is one of the example of theme created by others

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = 'grey25',
                 fill = 'grey90') +
  ggtitle('Distribution of Math scores') +
  theme_economist()






hrbrthemes
hrbrthemes are more focused on the typography instead of the overall beauty

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = 'grey25',
                 fill = 'grey90') +
  ggtitle('Distribution of Math scores') +
  theme_ipsum()





ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = 'grey25',
                 fill = 'grey90') +
  ggtitle('Distribution of Math scores') +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18,
              base_size = 15,
              grid = "Y")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
Beyond Single Graphs
sometimes plotting a single graph give minimum information. therefore, it is common to plot more than 1 graphic at the same time. this is to increase the amount of information and understanding extracted from the plots.

p1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Math scores")

p1





p2 <- ggplot(data = exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")

p2





p3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS,
                 y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm,
              size = 0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Math scores for Primary 3")

p3




here are 3 graphs plotted one after another. this way of plotting makes it hard to compare between them

Creating Composite Graphics: patchwork methods
patchwork is an extension of ggplot2

+ or | is used to create new column layout
() is used for subplots
/ is used for new row layout



2 Plots

columnrow



p1 + p2







p1 / p2









3 Plots

columnrowcombination



p1 + p2 + p3







p1 / p2 / p3






use “|” instead of “+” to use combination

(p1/p2)|(p3)









annotation(tag)

((p1/p2)|p3) +
  plot_annotation(tag_levels='I')






plot inside of plot

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)






patchwork + ggthemes

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()

title: Take-Home Exercise 1
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

1. Gender

MathScienceReading




Show the code
stats <- data.frame(gender = as.factor(c('Female','Male')),
                    mean = c(mean(stu_qqq$math[stu_qqq$gender == "Female"]),
                             mean(stu_qqq$math[stu_qqq$gender == "Male"])),
                    median = c(median(stu_qqq$math[stu_qqq$gender == "Female"]),
                               median(stu_qqq$math[stu_qqq$gender == "Male"])) )

ggplot(data = stu_qqq,
       aes(y = math)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10,
                 color = 'grey50',
                 fill = 'grey90') +
  facet_wrap(~ gender) +
  geom_hline(data = stats,
             mapping = aes(yintercept=mean),
             color = "red") +
  geom_hline(data = stats,
             mapping = aes(yintercept=median),
             color = "blue") +
  annotate(
    'text',
    x = Inf,
    y = Inf,
    hjust = 1,
    vjust = 2.1,
    label = paste("MEAN"),
    color = "red"
  ) +
  annotate(
    'text',
    x = Inf,
    y = Inf,
    hjust = 1,
    vjust = 1,
    label = paste("MEDIAN"),
    color = "blue"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

2. School

average_math_SG <- mean(stu_qqq$math)
average_scie_SG <- mean(stu_qqq$science)
average_read_SG <- mean(stu_qqq$read)

stu_qqq_sch <- stu_qqq %>%
  group_by(school_ID) %>%
  mutate(average_math_diff = abs(mean(math)-average_math_SG),
         average_science_diff = abs(mean(science)-average_scie_SG),
         average_read_diff = abs(mean(read)-average_read_SG)) %>%
  select(school_ID, average_math_diff, average_science_diff, average_read_diff) %>%
  unique() 



Show the code
p1 <- ggplot(data = stu_qqq_sch,
       aes(y = average_math_diff)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.1) +
  stat_summary(aes(x = 0),
               geom = "point",       
               fun.y ="mean",         
               colour ="red", 
               size=1) +
  xlim(c(-0.5,0.5)) +
